conclusion: Objects A and B are moved through the air and placed at the locations of objects C, D, E, and F, coming into contact with them due to gravity.
Object A is a stack of two rectangular blocks (one teal, one purple) on the left side of the coffee table.
Object B is a single purple cube on the right side of the coffee table.
Object C is the teal block in object A.
Object D is the purple block in object A.
Object E is the purple cube, which is object B.
Object F is a cushion on the couch behind the coffee table.
A and B are the objects being moved; C, D, E, and F are the target locations where A and B will be placed.
Since C and D are components of A, moving A to the location of C and D doesn’t make sense as a distinct action.
A is placed at F (a new location), and B is placed at C, D, and F.
Object A (the stack of blocks) is moved to the locations of E (B’s position on the table) and F (the cushion).
Object B (the purple cube) is moved to the locations of C and D (A’s original position on the table) and F (the cushion).
When A is placed at E, it lands on the coffee table where B was.
A doesn’t come into contact with E directly; it just sits on the table.
A remains stable on the flat surface of the coffee table.
When A is placed on the cushion, it comes into contact with the cushion (F).
Gravity pulls A downward, causing it to compress the cushion.
A might tilt or sink unevenly, but it will generally stay on the cushion.
When B is placed at the location of C and D, it lands on the coffee table where A used to be.
B doesn’t come into contact with C and D; it just rests on the table.
B sits stably on the flat surface of the coffee table.
